  <div id="readme" class="blob instapaper_body">
    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="mainContentOfPage"><h1><a id="user-content-classifying-barbell-lifts" class="anchor" href="#classifying-barbell-lifts" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Classifying barbell lifts</h1>

<h2><a id="user-content-practical-machine-learning-peer-assessment" class="anchor" href="#practical-machine-learning-peer-assessment" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Practical Machine Learning Peer Assessment</h2>

<h3><a id="user-content-july-2014" class="anchor" href="#july-2014" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>July 2014</h3>

<h2><a id="user-content-introduction" class="anchor" href="#introduction" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Introduction</h2>

<p>Using devices such as Jawbone Up, Nike FuelBand, and Fitbit it is now possible to collect a large amount of data about personal activity relatively inexpensively. One thing that people regularly do is quantify how much of a particular activity they do, but they rarely quantify how well they do it. Here we investigate a dataset where 6 participants were asked to perform barbell lifts correctly and incorrectly in 5 different ways, with accelerometers on the belt, forearm, arm, and dumbell. We build a classification model that can classify which way the participant is lifting the barbell, and then check this classification model against a test data set. </p>

<p>More information about this dataset is available from the <a href="#ref1">website (1)</a> specifically the section on the Weight Lifting Exercise Dataset. The <a href="#ref2">training data set(2)</a> and the <a href="#ref3">testing data set (3)</a> are also available.</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-methods" class="anchor" href="#methods" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Methods</h2>

<h3><a id="user-content-getting-and-preparing-the-data" class="anchor" href="#getting-and-preparing-the-data" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Getting and preparing the data</h3>

<p>First we load the training and testing data sets. Here it was necessary to pay attention to the fact that missing values could be represented in several ways, either by an <code>NA</code>, a totally empty value or <code>#DIV/0!</code> indicating a divide by zero error. In order to avoid numerical variables being erroneously converted to factor variables it was necessary to convert these values explicitly to NAs:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">train</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read.csv(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>data/pml-training.csv<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">na.strings</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>NA<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>#DIV/0!<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))
<span class="pl-smi">test</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read.csv(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>data/pml-testing.csv<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">na.strings</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>NA<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>#DIV/0!<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))
summary(<span class="pl-smi">train</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Second, examining the dataset, it is apparent that the different values of <code>classe</code> are grouped in sequential order so a model could appear to do very well just classifying based on the index. Therefore it is important to remove the id column, <code>x</code>, and any other column which could be used to place the values is sequential order such as timestamps. Also the names of the people who supplied the data are also grouped in sequential order so they need to be removed as well: </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">drops</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> c (<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>user_name<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>raw_timestamp_part_1<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>raw_timestamp_part_2<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>cvtd_timestamp<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>X<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>new_window<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
<span class="pl-smi">train.k</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">train</span>[,<span class="pl-k">!</span>(names(<span class="pl-smi">train</span>) <span class="pl-k">%in%</span> <span class="pl-smi">drops</span>)]
<span class="pl-smi">test.k</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">test</span>[,<span class="pl-k">!</span>(names(<span class="pl-smi">test</span>) <span class="pl-k">%in%</span> <span class="pl-smi">drops</span>)]</pre></div>

<p>Third, examining the dataset it was apparent that some columns had a lot of missing values, so we calculate how many missing values each column has and remove any columns that have too many missing values:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">n</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> dim(<span class="pl-smi">train.k</span>)[<span class="pl-c1">2</span>]
<span class="pl-smi">naCols</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> vector(<span class="pl-v">length</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">n</span>)
<span class="pl-k">for</span> (<span class="pl-smi">i</span> <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-smi">n</span>) { <span class="pl-smi">naCols</span>[<span class="pl-smi">i</span>] <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> sum(is.na(<span class="pl-smi">train.k</span>[,<span class="pl-smi">i</span>]))}
<span class="pl-smi">train.s</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.k</span>[,which(<span class="pl-smi">naCols</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">10</span>)]
<span class="pl-smi">test.s</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">test.k</span>[,which(<span class="pl-smi">naCols</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">10</span>)]</pre></div>

<p>Fourth, we we subdivide the training set to create a cross validation set. We allocate 70% of the original training set to the new training set, and the other 30% to the cross validation set:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">caret</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">inTrain</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> createDataPartition(<span class="pl-v">y</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">train.s</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-v">p</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0.7</span>, <span class="pl-v">list</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">training</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.s</span>[<span class="pl-smi">inTrain</span>,]
<span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.s</span>[<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-smi">inTrain</span>,]</pre></div>

<h3><a id="user-content-classification-and-regression-trees" class="anchor" href="#classification-and-regression-trees" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Classification and regression trees</h3>

<p>First we will investigate using classification and regression trees as proposed by <a href="#ref4">Breiman (4)</a> and <a href="#ref5">Ripley (5)</a>:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">tree</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">fit1</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> tree(<span class="pl-smi">classe</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> ., <span class="pl-v">method</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>tree<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">training</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">p1</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">fit1</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
table(<span class="pl-smi">training</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-smi">p1</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">fit1.prune</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> prune.misclass(<span class="pl-smi">fit1</span>, <span class="pl-v">best</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">10</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Figure 2 shows a pruned version of the generated tree in order to make the diagram legible. The full tree has 22 nodes so it is rather complex.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r,"><pre>plot(<span class="pl-smi">fit1.prune</span>)
title(<span class="pl-v">main</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Figure 1: Tree created using tree function<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
text(<span class="pl-smi">fit1.prune</span>, <span class="pl-v">cex</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1.2</span>)</pre></div>

<p>Does this complexity mean the tree is overfitting? We will investigate this using pruning. First though, we will estimate the in-sample error:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">nright</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-smi">p1</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">training</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>)
<span class="pl-v">tree_in_error</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.vector(<span class="pl-c1">100</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">nright</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>TRUE<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">/</span> sum(<span class="pl-smi">nright</span>)))</pre></div>

<p>We estimate the in-sample error to be <strong><code>r tree_in_error</code> %</strong>. Next, how does the tree perform on cross-validation set?</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">p2</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">fit1</span>, <span class="pl-v">newdata</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
table(<span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-smi">p2</span>)
<span class="pl-v">nright</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-smi">p2</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>)
<span class="pl-v">tree_out_error</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.vector(<span class="pl-c1">100</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">nright</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>TRUE<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">/</span> sum(<span class="pl-smi">nright</span>)))</pre></div>

<p>We estimate the out-of-sample error to be <strong><code>r tree_out_error</code> %</strong>. Can we improve performance on cross-validation set by pruning?</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">error.cv</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> {<span class="pl-c1">Inf</span>}
<span class="pl-k">for</span> (<span class="pl-smi">i</span> <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-c1">19</span>) {
    <span class="pl-smi">prune.data</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> prune.misclass(<span class="pl-smi">fit1</span>, <span class="pl-v">best</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">i</span>)
    <span class="pl-smi">pred.cv</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">prune.data</span>, <span class="pl-v">newdata</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
    <span class="pl-v">nright</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-smi">pred.cv</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>)
    <span class="pl-v">error</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.vector(<span class="pl-c1">100</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> ( <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">nright</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>TRUE<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">/</span> sum(<span class="pl-smi">nright</span>)))
    <span class="pl-smi">error.cv</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> c(<span class="pl-smi">error.cv</span>, <span class="pl-smi">error</span>) 
}
<span class="pl-smi">error.cv</span>
plot(<span class="pl-smi">error.cv</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>l<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">xlab</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Size of tree (number of nodes)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">ylab</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Out of sample error(%)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">main</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Figure 2: Relationship between tree size and out of sample error<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)</pre></div>

<p>Despite the complexity of the tree in Figure 1, Figure 2 does not indicate overfitting as the out of sample error does not increase as more nodes are added to the tree. </p>

<h3><a id="user-content-rpart-trees" class="anchor" href="#rpart-trees" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>RPart trees</h3>

<p>Next we will use a different type of classification and regression tree implemented by rpart, also as proposed by as proposed by <a href="#ref4">Breiman (4)</a>:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r,"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">rpart</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">fit2</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> rpart(<span class="pl-smi">classe</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> ., <span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">training</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">p3</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">fit2</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
table(<span class="pl-smi">training</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-smi">p3</span>)
library(<span class="pl-smi">rpart.plot</span>)
prp(<span class="pl-smi">fit2</span>, <span class="pl-v">cex</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1.3</span>)
title(<span class="pl-v">main</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span>  <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Figure 3: Tree constructed using the rpart function<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)</pre></div>

<p>Looking at the trees in Figure 1 and Figure 3 although the diagrams are different because they come from different packages there are similarities in the decisions they are using.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">cp</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">fit2</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">cp</span>
plot(<span class="pl-smi">cp</span>[,<span class="pl-c1">2</span>], <span class="pl-smi">cp</span>[,<span class="pl-c1">3</span>], <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>l<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">xlab</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Size of tree (number of nodes<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">ylab</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Out of sample error (%)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">main</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Figure 4: Relationship between tree size and out of sample error<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)</pre></div>

<p>Next we estimate the in-sample error:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">nright</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-smi">p3</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">training</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>)
<span class="pl-v">rpart_in_error</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.vector(<span class="pl-c1">100</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-smi">nright</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>TRUE<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">/</span> sum(<span class="pl-smi">nright</span>)))</pre></div>

<p>We estimate the in-sample error to be <strong><code>r rpart_in_error</code> %</strong> so it does slightly better than the <code>tree</code> package. Next, how does the tree perform on cross-validation set?</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">p4</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">fit2</span>, <span class="pl-v">newdata</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
table(<span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-smi">p4</span>)
<span class="pl-v">nright</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-smi">p4</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>)
<span class="pl-v">rpart_out_error</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.vector(<span class="pl-c1">100</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-smi">nright</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>TRUE<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">/</span> sum(<span class="pl-smi">nright</span>)))</pre></div>

<p>We estimate the out-of-sample error to be <strong><code>r rpart_out_error</code> %</strong>. Again this is an improvement on <code>tree</code>. </p>

<h3><a id="user-content-random-forests" class="anchor" href="#random-forests" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Random forests</h3>

<p>Next we apply random forests also proposed by <a href="#ref6">Breiman (6)</a> and <a href="#ref7">Breiman (7)</a>:</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">randomForest</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">fit3</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> randomForest(<span class="pl-smi">classe</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> ., <span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">training</span>, <span class="pl-v">method</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
<span class="pl-smi">p5</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">fit3</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
table(<span class="pl-smi">training</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-smi">p5</span>)
<span class="pl-v">nright</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-smi">p5</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">training</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>)
<span class="pl-v">forest_in_error</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.vector(<span class="pl-c1">100</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-smi">nright</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>TRUE<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">/</span> sum(<span class="pl-smi">nright</span>)))</pre></div>

<p>The in-sample error for the random forest is <strong><code>r forest_in_error</code> %</strong>. This is a big improvement over the two previous tree based methods. How does the forest perform on cross-validation set?</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">p6</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">fit3</span>, <span class="pl-v">newdata</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
table(<span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-smi">p6</span>)
<span class="pl-v">nright</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> table(<span class="pl-smi">p6</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-smi">train.cv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>)
<span class="pl-v">forest_out_error</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.vector(<span class="pl-c1">100</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-smi">nright</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>TRUE<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">/</span> sum(<span class="pl-smi">nright</span>)))</pre></div>

<p>The out-of-sample error for the random forest is <strong><code>r forest_out_error</code> %</strong>. Again this is much better than the previous tree based methods. </p>

<h2><a id="user-content-results" class="anchor" href="#results" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Results</h2>

<p>The random forest clearly performs better, approaching 99% accuracy for in-sample and out-of-sample error so we will select this model and apply it to the test data set. We use the provided function to classify 20 data points from the test set by the type of lift. We then upload these classifications to Coursera to confirm that the model is working correctly.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">destDir</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>./output<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
<span class="pl-v">pml_write_files</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>){
  <span class="pl-v">n</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> length(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>)
  <span class="pl-k">for</span>(<span class="pl-smi">i</span> <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-smi">n</span>){
    <span class="pl-v">filename</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> paste0(<span class="pl-smi">destDir</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>/<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>problem_id_<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,<span class="pl-smi">i</span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>.txt<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
    write.table(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>[<span class="pl-smi">i</span>],<span class="pl-v">file</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">filename</span>,<span class="pl-v">quote</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>,<span class="pl-v">row.names</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>,<span class="pl-v">col.names</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>)
  }
}
<span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-k">!</span>file.exists(<span class="pl-smi">destDir</span>)) {
    dir.create(<span class="pl-smi">destDir</span>)
}
<span class="pl-smi">p7</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">fit3</span>, <span class="pl-v">newdata</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">test.s</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
pml_write_files(<span class="pl-smi">p7</span>)</pre></div>

<p>With the random forest model, all twenty classifications correctly matched the test set values at Coursera.</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-conclusions" class="anchor" href="#conclusions" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Conclusions</h2>

<p>In this report we created three different classification models, using <code>tree</code>, <code>rpart</code> and <code>randomForest</code> for a data set of barbell lifts. We found the <code>randomForest</code> model performed the best, approaching accuracy of 99% for the out-of-sample data set. Using this model, we were able to correctly classify all twenty values from the test data set.</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-references" class="anchor" href="#references" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>References</h2>

<p><a name="user-content-ref1"></a>[1] Dataset <a href="http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har">http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har</a></p>

<p><a name="user-content-ref2"></a>[2] Training data set <a href="https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-training.csv">https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-training.csv</a></p>

<p><a name="user-content-ref3"></a>[3] Testing data set <a href="https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-testing.csv">https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-testing.csv</a></p>

<p><a name="user-content-ref4"></a>[4]  Breiman L., Friedman J. H., Olshen R. A., and Stone, C. J. (1984), Classification and Regression Trees. Wadsworth.</p>

<p><a name="user-content-ref5"></a>[5] Ripley, B. D. (1996), Pattern Recognition and Neural Networks., Cambridge University Press, Cambridge. Chapter 7.</p>

<p><a name="user-content-ref6"></a>[6] Breiman, L. (2001), Random Forests, Machine Learning 45(1), 5-32.</p>

<p><a name="user-content-ref7"></a>[7] Breiman, L (2002), Manual On Setting Up, Using, And Understanding Random Forests V3.1, <a href="http://oz.berkeley.edu/users/breiman/Using_random_forests_V3.1.pdf"> http://oz.berkeley.edu/users/breiman/Using_random_forests_V3.1.pdf</a></p>
